J. D, STEELE it Pl
CHAIRMAN : Ex-Officio Members

THOMAS'F. HUBBARD S B e\ HON. THEODORE R. MCKELDIN, MAYOR

_W. WATTERS PAGON :' . HON. JEROME SLOMAN,

MEMBER OF CITY COUNCIL
LUCIUS R. WHITE, Jr..

2T NATHAN L. SMITH,
P. ROSS BUNDICK e

DR. ROBERT L. JACKSON

COMMISS|ON ON CITY PLAN JOHN J. LANG, SECRETARY-ENGINEER.

400 MUNICIPAL BUILDING
BALTIMORE-2, MD.

July 1, 1945

Honorable Theodore R. McKeldin,
Mayor of the City of Baltimore,
Baltimore, Maryland.

®

Dear Mr. Mayor:

For a number of years Baltimore has faced a growing menace of
blight, gradually claiming more and more of the older part of the city.
With the pessing of time an area of some four square miles has become de-
preciated to the stage whers only the word "slum" adequately defines it.
This "slum” area is a very big, a very difficult, and a very pressing prob-
len,

v

-

The Commission on City Plan has recognized that some plan for
dealing with this slum area is vital to carrying out other phases of the
planning program; and, with the permission of the Honorable Board of Esti-
mates and appropriations for the employment of a ccnsultant, the Commission
undertoek this study to be carried into effect by our own staff.

We were fortunate in securing the services of Mr. Henry Vincent
Hubbard of Boston as consultant. Mr. Hubbard's experience among other
things includes:

°

Acting Chief -of the Town Planning /Division of the United States
Housing Corporation in World War I and editor of its final
report

For twenty-five years a member of the firm of Olmsted Brothers,
landscape architects, of Boston, Massaehusetts

For the past thirteen years a member of the National Perk and
Planning Commission for the Distriet of Columbia.

The report speaks for itself, and we confidently believe it will
be an intelligent guide to the new Baltimore Redevelopment Commission which
you have just appointed and to other agencies dealing with the housing :
problen.

Respectfully submitted,
COMMISSION O} CITY FLAN
/ J. D, Steele
i Chairmen

I »
.
-
/l
l’
I‘
